data.title: A Crash Course in a Century of Walt Disney Animation Studios
data.meta_description: From its first feature film, â€˜Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,â€™ to recent misses like â€˜Wish,â€™ hereâ€™s our crash course on the history of Disney Animation Studios.
data.text:
This story originally ran on January 11, 2021. Weâ€™ve updated it to include additional movies alongside the release of episode three of Land of the Giants: The Disney Dilemma, a Vultureâ€“Vox Media Podcast Network collaboration that looks at the many facets and ever-changing fortunes of the sprawling entertainment company. Episode three tries to understand how Disneyâ€™s beloved animated-feature-film operation has arrived at such an inconsistent place. You can listen to it here and follow the entire series at the Disney Dilemma hub.

The year 2023 marked a major milestone for one of the most powerful entertainment companies on the planet as the Walt Disney Company celebrated its 100th anniversary. Disney isnâ€™t the only movie studio that has passed its centennial, but its big birthday was particularly impressive considering its modest beginnings. Where other film studios were driven primarily to create and release live-action fare even in the silent era, perhaps Walt Disneyâ€™s most famous quote is that â€œit all started with a mouse.â€ Over its century-plus of existence, Walt Disney Animation Studios has morphed from a humble, small-time studio working on short films, to the first American purveyor of full-length, hand-drawn animated features, to making primarily computer-animated movies.

With the release of Land of the Giants: The Disney Dilemma, itâ€™s a fine time to revisit the Walt Disney Animation Studios canon on Disney+. Some of us diehards will tell you to watch every single title within that canon, but for the most important movies weâ€™ve created this crash course. For each era of the studioâ€™s feature-film history, we picked just two titles that best exhibit the period and its animators â€” but donâ€™t let that stop you from diving in deeper.

Need more help deciding where to start?

Sure, you could enjoy the canon chronologically. But if you want to skip to the titles that have exactly what youâ€™re looking for, weâ€™ve broken down the movies into some very scientific categories. To help you sort through the list, weâ€™ve added some handy emoji:

Golden Age (1937â€“42)

The quintessential classics that helped define a studio â€” and an entire medium of storytelling â€” make up the golden age of Disney Animation. Itâ€™s all killer, no filler.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„

Thereâ€™s no better place to start than with Disneyâ€™s first animated feature. This movie served as a template for so many other animated films from both Disney and its rivals. A winsome protagonist looking for her happily ever after? Check. Wacky sidekicks? Check. A terrifying villain hell-bent on gaining power? Check. Earworm songs? Check. But what makes Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs still groundbreaking 83 years later is the artistry on display.

This filmâ€™s technological breakthrough was the multiplane camera, a massive device that allowed the camera to â€œmoveâ€ through images of a forest or the forbidding castle where the Evil Queen plots the eponymous maidenâ€™s murder. Multiple animation cels (or images) were set up for each complex shot, making Snow White look as much like a movie as the live-action fare of the era did. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs isnâ€™t the gold standard of the Disney fairy tale, but you canâ€™t understand the studio without seeing how it all started.

Fantasia (1940) â¤ï¸ğŸ­ğŸª„ğŸ¦

Disneyâ€™s third animated feature, released just a few years after Snow White, was ambitious on a level rarely seen at any mainstream studio. Fantasia is unlike basically anything else Disney has ever done. Thereâ€™s no overall story, almost no dialogue, and few named characters. Itâ€™s hosted by an opera composer. Itâ€™s wall-to-wall classical music. And itâ€™s over two hours long. Fantasia may seem daunting, but itâ€™s well worth the effort (and if youâ€™re streaming it, you can watch the filmâ€™s eight sections in as many chunks as you like).

Each short in Fantasia allowed animators to flex their creative muscles. Tchaikovskyâ€™s Nutcracker Suite inspired the dancing flowers and mushrooms in the segment with that soundtrack, while The Rite of Spring describes nothing less than the evolution of life on Earth. (Fantasia isnâ€™t free of controversy: A group of Black female centaurs was removed from the original cut in the 1960s because they were depicted as servile.) But Fantasia failed to hit big initially. One reason it took so long to make a profit was that Walt Disney wanted a sound system installed in all theaters that was too expensive at the time. Dubbed Fantasound, it was stereo sound decades before the world was ready for it. Eighty years later, Fantasia is distinctive and remarkable, showcasing truly jaw-dropping animation.

Package Era (1941â€“49)

The combination of middling box-office returns for Pinocchio and Fantasia with the onslaught of World War II meant Walt Disney Studios had to scale back its production in the 1940s. (Disney was also conscripted by the government to make wartime propaganda.) Fantasia inadvertently signaled the creative strategy of these efforts, known as â€œpackageâ€ films: packages of short films that were shown together to achieve feature length.

The Reluctant Dragon (1941) ğŸ¦ğŸª„

The first notable package-film effort was a blend of live action and animation, black-and-white and color, and fiction and reality. The Reluctant Dragon is named for a Kenneth Grahame story, but only 20 minutes of the feature are given to its adaptation.

Beforehand, weâ€™re treated to comic gadfly Robert Benchley traversing the studio lot. Heâ€™s ostensibly there to see if Walt wants to adapt â€œThe Reluctant Dragon,â€ but first he takes a tour of everything from the recording booths (where he meets Clarence Nash, the voice of Donald Duck) to the storyboard rooms to where cast members mixed paint colors. The Reluctant Dragon also shows off the multiplane camera, the creation of sound effects for Dumbo, and more Disney magic. The film was released during a contentious animators strike, in which they demanded fairer wages and better labor practices; at the time, this self-driven love letter struck the wrong note. In context 80 years later, The Reluctant Dragon is a valuable, lo-fi look at how the sausage was made.

The Three Caballeros (1944) ğŸ¤ğŸ¦

Even in package films, Disney animators pushed boundaries. During their strike, Disney and a group of animators visited Latin America as part of the U.S. Good Neighbor Policy. Among the results of that trip were two package films: Saludos Amigos (1942) and The Three Caballeros. The former is barely a feature, clocking in at 42 minutes. But The Three Caballeros is adventurous and weird, as we watch Donald Duck learn about the cultures of Mexico, Brazil, and other Latin American nations.

The Three Caballeros, like all Disney package films, has its ups and downs. After an early stretch in which Donald watches a few â€œhome movies,â€ heâ€™s pulled into the action by his fellow caballeros, JosÃ© Carioca and Panchito Pistoles, and the movie comes to life. Even with its lower budget, The Three Caballeros is delightfully outlandish. The final section, titled â€œDonaldâ€™s Surreal Reverie,â€ shows the very horny duck drooling after women, and we see the caballerosâ€™ heads on real womenâ€™s bodies and other daffy images. Few Disney films are so singularly baffling and charming at once.

Silver Age (1950â€“59)

With WWII in the rearview, Disney entered a silver age, returning to fantastical worlds and fairy-tale adaptations with expanding technological ambition.

Cinderella (1950) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„

Disney went back to basics with a female-driven fairy tale that leans as much on its comic relief as Snow White does. Cinderella may seem as if itâ€™s about the blonde heroine, the sole servant at her evil stepmotherâ€™s house. Yet Cinderella is often a supporting character in her own story thanks to her wacky animal friends, the chatty mice Jaq and Gus.

Although youâ€™d think tension would be fully driven by whether or not Cinderella can go to the ball, fall in love with the prince, and escape her evil stepmotherâ€™s evil clutches, the film spends almost as much time pondering if the mice will get eaten by the nasty cat, Lucifer. Cinderella isnâ€™t as fancifully animated as the studioâ€™s earlier efforts, but there are flashes of the hallucinatory quality of the â€œPink Elephants on Paradeâ€ segment of Dumbo. Consider â€œSing, Sweet Nightingale,â€ a lullaby depicting the young maiden inside the soap bubbles sheâ€™s using to scrub the stairs. And few scenes in Disney animation rival the magical climax when Cinderella transforms into a beautiful princess with the help of her Fairy Godmother. Cinderella isnâ€™t groundbreaking, but sometimes the basics are enough.

Sleeping Beauty (1959) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„ğŸ’¥

The silver age wrapped up with Walt Disney and his animators balancing the visual ambition of Fantasia with the storytelling of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. More than 60 years later, itâ€™s widely agreed that Sleeping Beauty is a masterpiece, but when the film arrived in theaters, it did so with a thud. Reviewers and audiences were unmoved by the stately depiction of the story of Princess Aurora, who was cursed at birth by the evil fairy Maleficent to die on her 16th birthday.

Sleeping Beauty was the last true masterwork released during Walt Disneyâ€™s lifetime. The story is deceptively simple, but the way the animators create moving pictures to mimic medieval-style stained glass is singular. The filmâ€™s emotional arc mirrors the effect of the sleeping potion that overtakes Aurora and the denizens of the kingdom: Sleeping Beauty has a dreamlike quality as it drifts from one setpiece to the next until the climactic battle between Prince Phillip and the primally terrifying Maleficent-as-dragon. Disney bet the farm on Sleeping Beauty, and it paid off. This is one of the all-time great animated features, period.

Xerographic Era (1961â€“73)

Although Sleeping Beauty was a creative triumph, it was expensive and unprofitable, so the next era aimed to be cost-conscious. One of Walt Disneyâ€™s longtime cohorts, Ub Iwerks, had perfected xerographic technology for use in animation. The xerographic process (which utilized Xerox-style photocopying) eliminated the ink-and-paint process and brought animatorsâ€™ drawings right to the cel itself. Itâ€™s especially useful if youâ€™re making a movie about, say, 101 Dalmatians and you donâ€™t want to ink 101 sets of spots onto dogs of varying sizes.

One Hundred and One Dalmatians (1961) ğŸ¦ğŸ’¥

One Hundred and One Dalmatians was a major shift for Disney as the studioâ€™s first animated feature set in the present day. One of its most memorable images is a shot of scads of Dalmatian puppies watching a black-and-white TV set, a nod to the times. The film is also host to one of Disneyâ€™s most outlandish, disturbing villainesses, Cruella De Vil, whoâ€™s as evil as she sounds. From a visual standpoint, One Hundred and One Dalmatians isnâ€™t as lush or colorful as Sleeping Beauty, but itâ€™s a fun romp in which the technology matches the story.

The Jungle Book (1967) ğŸ¤ğŸ¦

In 1966, Walt Disney died, and the first animated feature released after his death wound up being the studioâ€™s best film for the ensuing two decades. The Jungle Book is more episodic than some post-package Disney features, by design. This Rudyard Kipling adaptation depicts â€œman-cubâ€ Mowgliâ€™s encounters with jungle animals as the officious Bagheera and lazy Baloo shepherd him to a village to save him from a vicious tiger. The Jungle Book features a great set of songs (including the unforgettable â€œThe Bare Necessitiesâ€), a killer score by undersung musical genius George Bruns, and beautiful, alluring animation that brings the jungle to life in ways the 2016 remake could only dream of.

While The Jungle Book has painterly touches and great character animation, a crash course in Disneyâ€™s animated features must also acknowledge that some of the studioâ€™s films include troubling depictions of nonwhite cultures. The Jungle Book is one such example, indulging in old-fashioned racism and sexism unhesitatingly. On Disney+, thereâ€™s a brief warning of offensive content, but the content is still jarring.

Dark Age (1977â€“85)

With most of the studioâ€™s fabled animators having retired and productions being scaled back, Disney entered a dark age of animation marked by edgier stories and alienated audiences.

The Rescuers (1977) ğŸ¦

The Rescuers was the last true gasp for the elder statesmen of Disney, as they offered this grim adaptation of Margery Sharpâ€™s daring rescue story. Depending on your point of view, this is an exciting adventure in which two mice rescue an orphan from a greedy kidnapper, or itâ€™s a bleak tragedy in which a little girl is so lost that only mice can save her. Either way, The Rescuers boasts impressively dark animated tableaux and fun, off-kilter chemistry between leads voiced by Bob Newhart and Eva Gabor. But as the studio continued leaning into darkness, it wound up alienating some audiences and animators.

The Black Cauldron (1985) ğŸª„ğŸ’¥

The 1980s were a time of abrupt change at Disney. After a group of animators led by Don Bluth (of The Secret of NIMH) walked out to start a rival company, the 1981 feature The Fox and the Hound struggled to come together. A few years later, Disney saw a bigger shift as Michael Eisner and Jeffrey Katzenberg arrived in the C-suite. When Katzenberg saw an early cut of The Black Cauldron, he was gobsmacked at its intense story line and graphic violence (for a Disney film). And he expected to cut it to ribbons just as he would edit a live-action film. (Animation editing doesnâ€™t work that way.)

The Black Cauldron is a creative misfire that gives a fascinating glimpse into Disneyâ€™s struggles. Itâ€™s the rare kind of stumble that offers viewers a chance to see a studio grappling with and attempting to reestablish its identity. This rough adaptation of Lloyd Alexanderâ€™s Chronicles of Prydain series is intended to be an epic adventure in the style of The Lord of the Rings, targeted at teenage boys. Sometimes, the film looks the part â€” presented in widescreen, some sections set in the kingdom of the Horned King (voiced by John Hurt) are moody and disturbing. But The Black Cauldron canâ€™t decide if it wants to be an â€™80s-era fantasy like Krull or Excalibur, or â€¦ you know, a â€œDisney movie.â€ On one hand: undead soldiers attacking the good guys. On the other: a chatty comic-relief sidekick asking for â€œmunchies and crunchies.â€ The Black Cauldron has fertile source material and some memorable images, but it was too schizophrenic to succeed.

Renaissance (1986â€“99)

The arrival of new executives and fresh blood in the animation studio allowed for a remarkable qualitative run. The Disney Renaissance is full of beloved favorites and box-office hits that remain among the studioâ€™s best.

The Little Mermaid (1989) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„

The hits came gradually. Smaller-budgeted films like The Great Mouse Detective reestablished Disney as a studio that still made entertaining family fare, and The Little Mermaid cemented the Disney Renaissance, making it clear that Disney was a force to be reckoned with. Like some of the studioâ€™s earliest successes, The Little Mermaid is an adaptation of a timeless fairy tale. Also like those early films, The Little Mermaid has a fearsome villain, hilarious sidekicks, and memorable music. But The Little Mermaid never keeps a fin stuck in the past.

The filmâ€™s co-directors, John Musker and Ron Clements, cut their teeth on The Great Mouse Detective before telling the story of Ariel, a passionate teenager who wants to spend time on dry land after she falls in love with the dashing Prince Eric. The true secret ingredient of The Little Mermaid is lyricist Howard Ashman; he and composer Alan Menken made their Disney debut with this film in melodically marvelous fashion. The songs are vastly indebted to the rich legacy of Broadway musicals, with â€œPart of Your Worldâ€ functioning as an â€œI Wantâ€â€“style number in which our heroine explains her innermost desires, and â€œPoor Unfortunate Soulsâ€ serving as the sea witch Ursulaâ€™s mission statement. Ashman and Menkenâ€™s songs are instantly unforgettable and necessary parts of the story.

The Lion King (1994) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸ¦ğŸ’¥

Two years after The Little Mermaid, Disney achieved the unthinkable: a Best Picture nomination for an animated film, the marvelous Beauty and the Beast. But for some audiences, the true high point of the renaissance arrived a few years later. The Lion King, a retelling of Shakespeareâ€™s Hamlet with anthropomorphized animals, galvanized audiences early. Disney presented the opening sequence as a teaser, a wise choice since â€œThe Circle of Lifeâ€ sets the tone for one of the most rousing scenes in Disney history. The ensuing film owes a lot to Bambi; the manner in which the stories are told is different, but the character arcs are awfully similar. Simba (voiced by Jonathan Taylor Thomas and Matthew Broderick) is next in line to rule the Pride Lands, but only after the tragic death of his father, Mufasa (James Earl Jones), does Simba realize the world is harsher than he figured from his cushy perch.

The Lion King isnâ€™t Disneyâ€™s greatest work â€” its structure is lopsided, making it so neither the young nor the adult Simba feels fully fleshed out â€” but it boasts gorgeous animation and some complex characterizations. Jeremy Irons delivers one of his best performances as Simbaâ€™s uncle, Scar, whose loathing for his family leads him to stage a coup and rule the Pride Lands into ruin. The Lion King was ambitious, hinting at future Disney Renaissance titles that attempted to balance the epic and the silly.

Turn of the Century (2000â€“8)

Disneyâ€™s problem with The Lion King was twofold: First, it was next to impossible for the studio to replicate or soar beyond its heights; second, less than 18 months later, Pixar released an animated film that shook the industry to its core. Toy Story was an excellent adventure that proved the viability of computer animation as a feature-length medium. Later Disney Renaissance titles couldnâ€™t compete, as Toy Story reminded the world that animated movies didnâ€™t all have to be like Broadway musicals. Although Pixarâ€™s films were consistently well liked and wildly successful, Disney CEO Michael Eisner had a contentious relationship with the then-chairman of Pixar, Steve Jobs. Even as Pixar was creating cash cow after cash cow, there was no sense that Disney leadership saw the value in fully absorbing the computer-animation studio.

Dinosaur (2000) ğŸ¦

Disney caught up only at the turn of the new century. In the summer of 2000, it released a computer-animated adventure. Like Toy Story, itâ€™s also song free. And itâ€™s â€¦ well, itâ€™s mostly computer animated. But Dinosaur doesnâ€™t have the same emotional impact or memorable characters as Pixarâ€™s offering. Its place in the studioâ€™s history is worth acknowledging, even as it represents one of Disneyâ€™s few modern lows.

Dinosaur is the story of an iguanodon and his adoptive family of lemurs traveling to safety in prehistoric times. The filmâ€™s most distinctive technical choice is to superimpose computer-animated characters against live-action backgrounds. Arguably, itâ€™s easier to convince audiences of the reality of a situation if the characters are traversing real places. But the animation in Dinosaur doesnâ€™t stand the test of time, and the story is wan and forgettable. Like The Lion King, Dinosaur was promoted in advance with a teaser version of its opening, in which a dinosaur egg travels down rushing waters. But Dinosaur goes downhill after this opening. The film is an effective warning: Animating a story via computer doesnâ€™t replace good dialogue and memorable characters.

Chicken Little (2005) ğŸ¦

The same is true of the lowest low of this era: Chicken Little. Yes, this is an adaptation of the famous fable about the tiny chicken who thinks the sky is falling. But that fable is brief, so this Chicken Little turns the story on its head. Now, Chicken Little (voiced by Zach Braff in the midst of his Scrubs fame) is right that the sky is falling â€¦ because itâ€™s the beginning of an alien invasion. Unfortunately, no one listens to him, especially not his gruff father, Buck Cluck, who just wants him to be a baseball star like Buck once was.

Arriving a decade after Toy Story, Chicken Little was Disneyâ€™s first fully computer-animated feature. Strangely, this film feels inspired by an outside rival: DreamWorksâ€™ Shrek. Like Shrek, Chicken Little is replete with pop-culture references, cameos, and needle drops. Also like Shrek, Chicken Little has some particularly grim-looking computer animation. The character design is garish, and coming opposite Finding Nemo and The Incredibles, itâ€™s easy to see why Chicken Little was less a path forward for the studio than a rough first attempt at embracing the future.

The Lasseter Era (2009â€“present)

After the false starts of the early 2000s, Disney did the smart thing and bought Pixar outright, installing its creative leader, John Lasseter, at the top of Disney Animation. Lasseter helped Disney right the ship and embrace computer animation while bidding hand-drawn animation one last farewell.

The Princess and the Frog (2009) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„ğŸ¦

From co-directors Musker and Clements, The Princess and the Frog broke creative ground by introducing the studioâ€™s first Black heroine. The film could have brought about a revival of hand-drawn animation; instead, it was the last stand.

This riff on â€œThe Frog Princeâ€ focuses on Tiana (Anika Noni Rose) â€” a hardworking young woman in 1920s New Orleans who is saving up to open a restaurant â€” and the misadventure she embarks upon after turning into a frog. The Princess and the Frog is a modern pinnacle of Disney animation. With songs by Randy Newman, the film boasts the same showstopping Broadway-style music of the Disney Renaissance, coupled with a rare romance in which both partners are fully characterized and developed. The budding relationship between Tiana and her beau, Prince Naveen, works because, as with Beauty and the Beast, both characters get enough screen time to make you believe they would fall in love at all. The Princess and the Frog might have stumbled at the box office, but itâ€™s an incredible curtain call for Disneyâ€™s hand-drawn days.

Zootopia (2016) â¤ï¸ğŸ¦

The shift to computer animation in the 2010s was more effective for Disney. Frozen and Tangled proved that princess stories could be handled via computer, yet the studio found one of its biggest hits by echoing Pixarâ€™s predilection for mismatched buddies. Zootopia at its heart is a buddy comedy with a do-gooder cop (Ginnifer Goodwin) teaming up with a sneaky criminal (Jason Bateman) to solve a slew of missing-mammals cases in the eponymous metropolis. â€œMammalsâ€ clues you in to the gimmick: All the characters are animals, from rabbits to foxes to wolves and more.

Zootopia is deft, funny, and the most richly animated film the studio has made in years. Goodwin and Bateman are a hilarious team, and the pacing is crisp enough to stand next to live-action action movies. The filmâ€™s attempts to draw parallels to racism in the real world are the big stumble, highlighting how parallels between animals and humans go only so far. But the story, inventive humor, and emotionally deep voice performances make Zootopia a fine closer to this crash course.

Walt Disney Animation Studios has progressed beyond its days of only telling fairy tales with standard templates and characters. But in recent features, thereâ€™s plenty you can recognize that was inspired by colorful stories of fair young maidens, dashing princes, and frightening antagonists. As Disney enters the 2020s with more questions than answers about where the medium will take it, there has never been a better time to stream the studioâ€™s past to see how far it has come.

Brand Deposit Era (2016-2020)

For decades, Disneyâ€™s animation studio eschewed making theatrically released sequels to its beloved classics, with only a few exceptions. But in the twilight years of Bob Igerâ€™s first go-round as CEO, and with the massive success of many live-action/CGI remakes of animated classics, their strategy changed.

Moana (2016) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„

The animated musical Moana straddled older and younger generations, not just with its broad-based appeal but in its very creation. The filmâ€™s co-directors, John Musker and Ron Clements, had helped kick off the Renaissance era with films like The Great Mouse Detective and The Little Mermaid. But where those films were proudly hand-drawn, Moana is primarily computer-animated with just a few choice hand-drawn touches, like sentient tattoos. Like The Little Mermaid, Moana is a musical with songs created by immensely talented Broadway composers. In particular, Moana had the good fortune to boast music from Lin-Manuel Miranda, fresh off the worldwide phenomenon of Hamilton. And like another Musker-Clements film, Aladdin, Moana features a massively famous star (Dwayne Johnson) in a wisecracking supporting role that audiences fell for.

So itâ€™s no surprise that Moana is the last truly great Walt Disney Animation Studios film to date, taking its eponymous Pacific Islander heroine on a journey to restore the heart of the ocean while she learns some valuable life lessons and makes a new friend in the gregarious demigod Maui. Moana is the kind of film that Disney excelled at making once, blending instantly memorable songs (an underrated number is â€œShiny,â€ performed by Jemaine Clement as a David Bowieâ€“esque monster crab) with vibrant and colorful animation, a relatable story, and hilarious sidekicks. Naturally, Disney has decided to give it a sequel, arriving in November 2024, as well as a live-actionâ€“CG remake in 2026, once again starring Johnson as Maui. Youâ€™re welcome?

Frozen II (2019) ğŸ¤ğŸª„ğŸ’¥

Frozen II wasnâ€™t even the first sequel of the brief Brand Deposit era within the Walt Disney Animation Studios. That dubious honor goes to Ralph Breaks the Internet, a fine if unremarkable follow-up to Wreck-It Ralph that is primarily memorable for a scene in which a slew of Disney princesses are glimpsed hanging out with the cheerfully obnoxious Vanellope von Schweetz. But the hype for Frozen II was undeniable, guaranteeing its smash-hit status at the box office. The original Frozen is slightly messy from a storytelling perspective, but it looks like a paragon of screenwriting compared to this grimmer follow-up, in which we learn that Anna and Elsaâ€™s family tree was even more problematic than we thought.

Frozen II does have at least one great song, â€œInto the Unknown,â€ but arguably its most fascinating element is the corresponding behind-the-scenes docuseries, also titled Into the Unknown. If youâ€™re ever curious about how the animated sausage is made, youâ€™d do well to check out the series (streaming on Disney+), specifically to grasp how much of this movie was picked apart and made on the fly, sometimes to the detriment of story-based logic. (If Elsaâ€™s mother told her as a child to hide her powers, why would she then later tell Elsa to â€¦ not hide her powers?) But even though Frozen II was not as creatively successful as its predecessor, it was a billion-dollar grosser, which is probably all Iger and his fellow execs focused on.

The COVID Era (2021â€“present)

Although the COVID-19 pandemic caused major shake-ups around the entertainment world, Walt Disney Animation Studios kept on releasing new animated titles. However, theyâ€™ve struggled to stand out from the competition.

Encanto (2021) â¤ï¸ğŸ¤ğŸª„

Itâ€™s a strange twist of fate that the biggest recent success from Walt Disney Animation Studios didnâ€™t light a fire in theaters. On the one hand, few people would deny that Encanto was ubiquitous for many months â€” as you read the words â€œWe Donâ€™t Talk About Bruno,â€ youâ€™re probably struggling to not break into song. On the other hand, the box-office results werenâ€™t pleasant with the film grossing $96 million domestically owing to pandemic-era low turnouts. Once Disney put Encanto on Disney+ over the 2021 holiday season, though, the film went viral. While Encanto does have its charms, itâ€™s a slightly dull echo of other titles.

Much like the Pixar film Coco, Encanto is a colorful depiction of a tight-knit Latin American family, and, much like Moana, a lot of the strength of the film is derived from catchy songs courtesy of Miranda. If there is a problem with the Walt Disney Animation Studios of the 2020s, itâ€™s that the studioâ€™s identity seems less clear than it used to be, and Encanto, with its episodic story and bursting-at-the-seams ensemble, feels like a slew of interesting ideas that arenâ€™t able to hold enough focus. The movie is cute enough, but the signs of potential trouble for future titles are present.

Wish (2023) ğŸ¤ğŸª„

As noted in the introduction, Disney celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2023, and one of the many ways in which it wanted to commemorate the milestone was through a new animated film. In concept, that film, Wish, was a slam dunk. Few words are more synonymous with Disney movies than wish, and taking that word and turning it into a story in which a winsome young heroine is partnered with a literal wishing star to stop a power-mad leader seems like a gimme. But concept and execution are different things, and Wish is, in execution, one of the weakest and oddest films Walt Disney Animation Studios has ever made. Even its most daring choice, to boast an art style that combines computer-animated and watercolor-style backgrounds, alienated some viewers (though I would say that choice was one of the filmâ€™s only successful aspects).

Despite featuring the always game Ariana DeBose as the lead and Chris Pine gleefully portraying the first genuine bad guy a Disney animated film has had in a while, Wish stumbles as soon as it delivers its world-building premise, set in a city where everyone has a deeply felt wish that they have given over to Pineâ€™s baddie, a whim-driven ruler who decides which scant wishes can come true. The number of questions that concept raises without answering â€” thereâ€™s even a scene late in the film when other characters ask the villain some of these questions â€” only serves to show how little thought was placed into Wish. The result is a film that feels very much like an executive edict to tie in to the Disney100 celebration, a birthday surprise that never actually took off.
